indicators.justification:
The national memory on questions relating to climate change is ensured by the general directorate for the environment and climate (1). It covers all aspects including the issue of greenhouse gas emissions (2). There have been several national conventions on the subject in connection with the respect of the commitments made by Benin at the international level. With the exception of reports, there are no searchable figures for decision making(3).

Sources:
(1) https://www.changementsclimatiques.bj
(2) https://unfccc.int/sites/default/files/resource/47806591_Benin-BUR1-1-BENIN_RAPPORT_NATIONAL%20INVENTAIRE_GES.pdf
(3) https://www.bj.undp.org/content/benin/fr/home/presscenter/articles/la-gestion-durable-des-terres-agricoles-pour-la-biomasse-au-beni.html

indicators.justification:
The first(1) and sixth national reports (2) on the United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity provide information on all the data sought but we do not have an available and updatable database to report on it. These are periodic data collections that allow us to have a snapshot of the information over time to produce the national report. The methodology for writing data collections and writing reports is well indicated in the documents. It also emphasizes the difficulties and limitations.

Source:
(1) https://www.cbd.int/doc/world/bj/bj-nr-01-fr.pdf
(2) https://www.cbd.int/doc/nr/nr-06/bj-nr-06-fr.pdf

evidence.title: The Fourth National Report on the United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity
The First National Report on the United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity

indicators.justification:
The Benin document entitled United Nations Framework Convention on Climate (1) Change provides follow-up to the questions asked. This is aggregated data and the details are the product of specific data collection (2). There is still a lack of a platform (3) to collect regular data together with the observation of major trends(4). The agroecological atlas allows us to assess the impact of climate change on maize production, for example (5).

Sources:
(1) https://unfccc.int/resource/docs/natc/bennc1f.pdf
(2) https://www.cbd.int/doc/nr/nr-06/bj-nr-06-fr.pdf
(3) https://www.changementsclimatiques.bj/
(4) https://www.cbd.int/doc/world/bj/bj-nbsap-v2-fr.pdf
(5) https://www.weadapt.org/sites/weadapt.org/files/legacy-new/knowledge-base/files/4f736d21b6a25projet-de-travail-saturnin-draft-final-2-projectplace-132017.pdf

indicators.justification:
Business creation procedures are facilitated in Benin (1). It is possible to start a business in less than a day if the necessary parts are provided online (2). In this procedure, the identities of the owner and those of his associates are provided including their gender. However, while this data is provided, is not made public. To have access to the identity of the owners of the companies, it is necessary to go to the agency of promotion of the investments and the exports (3) or to the general direction of the taxes (4).

Sources:
(1) https://www.gouv.bj/actualite/512/lapiex-lance-monentreprise.bj-plateforme-de-creation-et-de-formalisation-en-ligne-des-entreprises-au-benin/
(2) https://monentreprise.bj/
(3) https://www.apiex.bj/
(4) https://ifu.impots.bj/ifu-search

indicators.justification:
Business data is not available as open data in Benin. The law doesn't also provide provisions on this. The structures which hold this information make it a private preserve. To use it, you must make a case for why you need the data. Data are available from APIEX (1) and the General Tax Directorate (2). Access is subject to a reasoned request. The business creation platform is a data hotbed (3).

Sources:
(1) https://benindoingbusiness.bj/?l=fr
(2) http://www.impots.finances.gouv.bj/
(3) https://monentreprise.bj/

indicators.justification:
Data on birth and death rates are sensitive. They are often the subject of several speculations. This research did not find any birth and death declaration database. However,part of this data at the health centres where birth and death registers are kept. There are also central information in the national identification agency(1).

Source:
(1) https://www.anip.bj/

indicators.justification:
The health information system is not yet sufficiently tested. The referencing of patients is not yet refined. It is important to ensure that any doctor is able to observe on a single platform the hospital beds that can be used over time. Today, the centres are called to present the technical platform and confirm bed availability before initiating patient transfers. Law (1) on the protection of human health in the Republic of Benin provides details on the operation of public and private health centers and clarifies the relationship between the patient and the health professional. Covid19 information are centralised by government(2).

Sources:
(1) https://documentation-anbenin.org/s/textes-de-lois/item/2188
(2) https://www.gouv.bj/coronavirus/

indicators.justification:
Land data is under the control of specialized state structures on land issues. The geodetic database is available at the national geographic institute (1). It was set up with the support of several international organizations including the UNDP Benin. Land data is also available at the level of the national estate and land agency. A national cadastre (2) is in progress. It has already enabled the collection of detailed data from 10 municipalities. For all the land information needs, it is necessary to go to the actors who are the owners. The uploading of data is still quite slow. The data that are made available online are not very detailed. They are not exportable for use either.

Source:
(1) https://ign.bj/nos-services/
(2) https://cadastre.bj/

indicators.justification:
Data on land is very important for development. Security of tenure is a way to safeguard investments and encourage investors. However, to have exhaustive data today in Benin, you have to go physically to the national agency in the field or enter them through their platform (1). You will be billed for the information the agency provides to you. Almost all information is invoiced. There is just general information of no great importance that is viewed online without the possibility of printing. It is also important to note that some data fields are still not filled in online and the agency encourages the alleged owners to provide it with data via its platform (2). Data on natural persons who own land are not available online. A platform is set up and is informed by the contribution of the alleged landowners. For the ten municipalities with the online digital cadastre, owners of land titles whose individual data is not online are invited to provide them. The system allows natural persons to enter their data online.

Source:
(1) https://www.andf.bj/index.php
(2) https://cadastre.bj/?lat=712578.3674999999&lon=377948.3785&zoom=19

indicators.justification: We have data on the general state budget and its execution but it does not exist in the form of open data. We even have state budget analysis reports to see its sensitivity to gender, climate change and more. Depending on the challenges of the moment, the state budget is strongly oriented towards certain sectors to the detriment of others. It is a governance tool that makes it possible to materialize the promises made in development policy documents.

indicators.justification:
It is when the parties want to receive public funding that they act on the ground by collecting justifications to face the control of the public resource received from the state. They are also looking for proof of reimbursement of election campaign expenses when they have obtained more than 10% of the national vote in an election. Data on membership dues, donations, and other support from members and supporters should be made public. Expenditure should also be made public to allow confirmation if necessary. Political parties have been trained in the management of public funds made available to them for the financing of political activities(1).
Source:
(1) https://budgetbenin.bj/seminaire-de-formation-des-partis-politiques-sur-les-procedures-de-gestion-et-de-controle-des-fonds-publics/

indicators.justification: The right to information is guaranteed by law in Benin. But citizens will tell you it's on paper. In practice, nothing is done to give information to everyone. The people would have liked to have a free access data warehouse for the information produced by all public structures without exception. We are far from this ideal. We must not lose sight of the fact that information gives power. In the history of Benin, there has not yet been a case where those who govern, make all information available in the public domain. The current government is the one that has the palm of the control of the information to be made available to the people.

indicators.justification:
Data from public consultations is the property of the organizations that initiate them. Data is not always disseminated online. Public consultations are an invaluable mass of data that can be used for decision support. If this data can be concentrated in a database and gradually enriched, that would be great. Data produced with public funds should be fully online for everyone to use. But to achieve this, we must take a specific law to constrain the producers of information who have had public resources to transmit their data in a national data warehouse. Access to information is essential for the transparency of public management (1).
Source:
(1) https://www.wathi.org/laboratoire/tribune/droit-dacces-a-linformation-efficacite-transparence-de-gestion-publique-benin/

The data includes final regulations and justifications.
The data includes details of challenges to regulations that have passed through public consultation processes, as well as the results of these challenges.
Dataset is available free of charge.

indicators.justification:
Public contracts are quite sensitive and the relevant state services pay all their attention to it. All the services offered by the state are implemented within the framework of an agreement between the stakeholders. This agreement is materialized by a contract that is based on the terms of reference of the requested service/goods. The public procurement system is organized around several interdependent actors to guarantee transparency in the process. There are in particular a contracting authority, a public procurement unit, a control entity, an expenditure payment entity and other entities that control the accuracy and quality of the service. Public procurement is at the heart of good governance of public affairs(1).

Source :
(1) https://www.marches-publics.bj/

indicators.justification:
This is an important question. For an environment where data is not yet open access for all, we are far from imagining initiatives aimed at the reuse of open data. It is a futuristic step within the framework of the current observation environment. The consultation is open and will show the do way (1).
 
Source:
(1) https://assi.bj/doc/Marches-publics/2020/AMI%20PORTAIL%20NATIONAL%20OPEN%20DATA.pdf

indicators.justification:
Independently of the initiative of the data platform set up by the national statistical institute in Benin (1), a global reflection is underway on the question of open data. Indeed, on behalf of the government of Benin, the national agency for information systems and services (2) is piloting an open data file. This file is made in relation to the French development agency and the World Bank. The process is still in its early stages and no public visibility is given to this file. Consultations continue between the stakeholders to finalize the financial support necessary for the concrete implementation of the project. An agent is dedicated to this project within the services and information systems agency and consultation in open (3).

Sources:
(1) https://benin.opendataforafrica.org/
(2) https://assi.bj/
(3) https://assi.bj/doc/Marches-publics/2020/AMI%20PORTAIL%20NATIONAL%20OPEN%20DATA.pdf

Senior political leaders back the open data initiative.

responses.response_text: The open data initiatives covers much of both national and sub-national government.

indicators.justification:
We do not have training in data scientist in Benin. Even if this were the case, this agent profile has not yet been recruited at the level of local authorities in Benin. Data collection is often carried out and published by the national statistical institute (1) which involves representatives of local communities. The role played by the latter in the context of data collection operations does not offer them the skills to collect specific data and even less to analyze them for decision-making purposes. The data concerning each local authority is available at the level of the national statistical institute. There is also CONAFIL which produces statistical data on the local finances of municipalities in Benin (2).

Sources:
(1) https://insae.bj/
(2) https://donnees.banquemondiale.org/pays/benin

responses.response_text: There is no evidence of capability to effectively manage data.

There is evidence of local governments providing support for data reuse.

indicators.justification:
In Benin, there is no national training or capacity building process on data for the benefit of civil servants. However, the national statistics institute offers training in statistics (1) for those who are interested, including civil servants. 

Learners who do their training at the National Institute of Statistics, obtain a certificate of end of training. There is also training in statistics with the national statistics institute in Cotonou. If you want to take part in their training, you have to live in Cotonou.

Source:
(1) https://insae.bj/bon-a-savoir/53-centre-de-formation-professionelle-de-l-insae-cfpi

Training delivered covers data analysis, visualisations and storytelling techniques.

Training on data addresses non-technical public servants.
Training on data is focused on specific positions already working with data.
Training is planned by an established training team, department, or agency.
Public servants receive a certification when taking a training so there is a formal recognition as a professional development.

indicators.justification:
In March 2020, the people of Benin were informed of an initiative to set up a national interoperability platform. It is a file which is still in progress. The finalization of the project will surely allow to know more about what the platform allows to do. But, the first idea is to have a tool that allows the interchange of information between the different specific platforms of the Beninese administrations.
Cina Lawson, Benin: a national interoperability platform planned, March 23, 2020,  https://www.ict4africa.net/2020/03/23/benin-une-plate-forme-nationale-dinteroperabilite-en-projet/

responses.response_text: The datasets do not share common identifiers.

The key datasets for this theme share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The different political integrity datasets use common identifiers for public officials.
Lobbying data and political finance data share common identifiers for lobbyist clients and party and campaign donors.
Lobbying registers and public consultation data use common identifiers for regulations.
Asset declarations and political finance disclosures share common identifiers for interests, assets, and liabilities.
The various datasets share common identifiers for legal persons associated with donations, interests, assets, liabilities, and lobbying activities.
The key datasets for the political integrity and company information modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and land modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public finance modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public procurement modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.

indicators.justification:
There is no provision neither provisional, nor final, nor administrative, nor legal of which we can appreciate the definition and its extent. For information on the ownership of a company, contact the Director General of the Investment and Export Promotion Agency (1). Since companies have a unique tax identifier, a copy of the information is also available from the Directorate General of Taxes. Every citizen, every business and every organization can obtain their unique tax identifier free of charge (2). The digital officer sets up the conditions and obligations for updating personal data. It however is silent on other types of data and on evidence.

Sources:
(1) http://www.gufebenin.org/
(2) https://ifu.impots.bj/ifu-request

indicators.justification:
Article 58 of the Law on the Protection of Persons with Disabilities (1) obliges the state to provide them with information services. One of the objectives of the national policy for the protection of people with disabilities provides that access to information and communication is guaranteed to them throughout the national territory (2).

indicators.justification:
The data is not specifically taken into account by law and even less by the National Statistics Council (1). There is a restrictive view that observes personal data in the digital code (2) and information in the information code (3). We are still a long way from the structural dynamics of the production and supply of data to facilitate its use by researchers, innovators and data professionals. We are entitled to wonder about the potential for exploiting artificial intelligence technologies that Benin can put in place in this current data society.

Source:
(1) https://www.google.fr/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=&cad=rja&uact=8&ved=2ahUKEwjx8LOLmbTzAhVNPBoKHUh7CP4QFnoECAMQAQ&url=https%3A%2F%2Fsgg.gouv.bj%2Fdoc%2Floi-99-014%2Fdownload&usg=AOvVaw0JDqlpP8ms2wq1fE1cPhWo

responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
There are minimum standards for metadata when government data is catalogued or published.
There is a standardised process for publishing and updating published government data.
There are technical standards, including common data models, codelists, and identifiers for management and publication of government data.
There are clearly documented quality control processes for government data.
There are clearly documented processes for soliciting and integrating feedback from external users to improve data quality.

indicators.justification:
The law on information and communication (1) speaks of the dissemination of information and not of the sharing of data.

The sharing of information from public sources is compulsory for all organizations and all public officials under the provisions of Articles 70, 71 and 72 of the Information and Communication Code. This rule is also valid in the context of information sharing between public administrations.
Article 72 of the Information and Communication Code indicates that public sources of information are exercised regardless of the form of the document: written, graphic, sound, visual, computerized or other.
The Information and Communication Code requires everyone to have access to public sources of information without discrimination.
In Benin, the information and communication code and the related decrees and orders are applied nationally.

Source:
(1) https://sgg.gouv.bj/doc/loi-2015-07/download

responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
The framework covers data sharing within government.
The framework covers how government should share data with other sectors.
The framework covers data sharing from other sectors to government.
The framework covers data sharing within the private sector.
The framework explicitly focuses on artificial intelligence uses of data.

indicators.justification:
Benin's digital code (Loi n°2017-20 du 20 avril 2018 portant code du numérique en République du Bénin) (1) is devoted to personal data. This book addresses all aspects of the issue of personal data. It was set up following a large series of consultations that allowed for the consideration of practices, laws, treaties, conventions and regulations that address the issue at the level of ECOWAS, the African Union, the European Union and the United Nations.

Source:
(1) https://sgg.gouv.bj/doc/loi-2017-20/download

responses.response_text: A framework exists and has the force of law.

The framework sets out clear responsibilities for data holders.
The framework provides rights of redress
The framework requires data controllers to notify an appropriate authority of data breaches.
Frameworks explicitly cover the protection of location-related data.
The framework addresses algorithmic decision making.
Exceptions to the usual data protection framework have been made as part of the country's COVID-19 response.

responses.response_text: The framework applies widely across all sectors (including public and private sector).

indicators.justification:
For surveys that aim to calculate socio-economic data, the national statistics council (1) must examine and validate the collection methodology and the results obtained before their official publication (2).
The producer of the information is responsible for convincing the members of the National Statistics Council of the admissibility of the data and the expected results.
The law applies throughout the territory. But in practice, the national statistics council does not always have the means to control the producers of information that are not addressed to it.
Therefore, there are press releases for the respect of the law on the production of statistics. This law does not oblige the council to make the data publicly available for mass use. You have to go to the institute for all data needs, especially needs related to detailed data that are very useful to scientists.

Source:
(1) https://www.google.fr/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=&cad=rja&uact=8&ved=2ahUKEwjx8LOLmbTzAhVNPBoKHUh7CP4QFnoECAMQAQ&url=https%3A%2F%2Fsgg.gouv.bj%2Fdoc%2Floi-99-014%2Fdownload&usg=AOvVaw0JDqlpP8ms2wq1fE1cPhWo

(2) http://ortb.bj/societe/collecte-de-donnees-statistiques-le-gouvernement-appelle-au-respect-des-procedures/

responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
Where does this requirement exist?
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.

indicators.justification:
Benin is still very far from the adoption of a law or the implementation of an open data directive. Discussions are barely open on the subject. However, media players encourage and call for the opening of a public debate on the issue (1). There is a law on the code of information and communication (2) which authorizes media players to have access to public sources of information without anything being said about the format of this information. In practice, it is the publications of reports that are made accessible and not the primary data that can be crossed for multiple analytical purposes. In 2016, training was given to journalists for the collection and use of open data, but the law is still silent on the subject (3). The national statistical institute has set up a data portal with the support of the African Development Bank (4). The bailout of this data platform remains a challenge. A specific law would make it easier for everyone and gives academics the chance to have massive data for more judicious use.

Sources:
(1) http://placetodo.org/benin-route-vers-lopen-data/

(2) https://sgg.gouv.bj/doc/loi-2015-07/download

(3) https://cfi.fr/fr/projet/opendata-medias

(4) https://benin.opendataforafrica.org/

responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
The framework establishes a common definition of open data.
The framework promotes open licensing without any restrictions beyond attribution and share-alike.
The framework requires to publish data in machine readable formats.
The rules/guidance requires the use of specific data standards.
The framework promotes training and capacity building among government officials.

indicators.justification:
Budget transparency (1) is a requirement of the countries of the West African Monetary Union. Local (2) finances are also affected by budget transparency in the West African monetary union. An annual report from the West African Monetary Union takes stock of economic developments. Here is an example of the union's annual report (3). Benin is a good student when it comes to budget transparency. The finance law is passed on the right date with the production of all the framework and execution documents for the general state budget. Information on external resource mobilization and debt is also available. Regular arbitration is made with the financial technical partners to guarantee the mobilization of pledges of resources and the efficient consumption of credits and grants. Before the vote on the finance law for each year n + 1, the draft of the general state budget is often made available for criticism by civil society (4) organizations interested in governance. These criticisms shed light on the budget debate in the National Assembly and may induce corrections before the vote. Budget guidelines are specific from one year to the next. They take into account the challenges of the moment.

Sources:
(1) http://www.uemoa.int/sites/default/files/bibliotheque/directive_01_2009_cm_uemoa.pdf
(2) http://www.uemoa.int/sites/default/files/bibliotheque/directive_01_2011_cm_uemoa.pdf
(3) http://www.uemoa.int/sites/default/files/bibliotheque/uemoa_rapport_annuel_sur_le_fonctionnement_de_l-union_2020.pdf
(4) https://socialwatch.bj/?p=1656

indicators.justification:
The LAW N° 2011-20 OF OCTOBER 12, 2011 On the fight against corruption and other related offenses in the Republic of Benin (1); and LAW No 2020-09 OF APRIL 23, 2020 On the creation, mission, organization and operation of the High Commissioner for the prevention of corruption in the Republic of Benin (2) cover the asset declarations in the public sector. They specify the officers that have to complete the declarations, when officers have to present them, who is in charge of receiving them, and the sanctions in case of not compliance. 

Sources:
(1) https://sgg.gouv.bj/doc/loi-2011-20/download
(2) https://sgg.gouv.bj/doc/loi-2020-09/download

indicators.justification: The word lobbying is not always well received in Benin. It is often put in the same basket as corruption. The related data is not public and it is difficult to assess it. There is no formal data on this subject in the Beninese scientific and administrative literature.

indicators.justification:
Decree (1) for financing the political parties for the year 2020 was issued in Benin. It is made in application of Law (2) on the financing of political parties in the Republic of Benin. This provision made it possible to allocate three billion to the three (3) political parties eligible for public funding after the 2020 elections, for the year 2021. But before, each party sought funds to finance its activities. So far, the practice of public funding has not yet been well tested. Supporting documents for expenditure are provided to the competent authorities. No information filters on the use made of resources let alone the evidence of uses. Data on party funding is not available online, and the law and regulations do not provide for the release of the data. The political parties produce the receipts of expenses and submit them to whom it may concern. There is no public accountability for the use of political party funding.


Sources:
(1) http://levenementprecis.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/D%C3%A9cret-2020-362-portant-financement-des-partis-politiques.pdf
(2) https://documentation-anbenin.org/s/textes-de-lois/item/2060
(3) https://archives.beninwebtv.com/2020/09/benin-liste-des-partis-politiques-eligibles-au-financement-de-letat-en-2020/

indicators.justification: The rule development process does not always take place through public consultation. It is a new participatory governance approach to which Benin will gradually adapt. In this process, the primary data collected and the summary made are made public. Laws and regulations have not yet instituted this mode of operation. Consultations with stakeholders are requested to improve decision-making or refine the content of collaborative writing. The public consultation, which is often carried out, brings together the target groups according to the subjects. It is done in a local and face-to-face environment. This is not always information available online. With social networks, we are increasingly seeing the recording of audios and / or videos of these sessions that we find online thanks to the action of goodwill.

indicators.justification: The right to information is guaranteed by the constitution in Benin. There is the information and communication code which specifies the modalities of its application. But in practice, there is an information warfare that is established. The law says we have the right to information but nothing helped.

The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.

responses.response_text: The framework covers the entire public sector.
responses.subquestion_text: How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the framework assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
Business (1) data is not available as open data. Even if organizations manage to have some of this data, they cannot use it for innovation because of the clauses of access to this data. The companies that own the data remain the sole owners of the data. They are accountable for this before the law, in particular on aspects relating to personal data governed by the digital code (2).

Source:
(1) https://monentreprise.bj/
(2) https://sgg.gouv.bj/doc/loi-2017-20/download

responses.response_text: There is no evidence of such products or services in the country.

indicators.justification:
Benin is yet to make much progress on initiatives aimed at using open data on land holdings (1) for the implementation of a law or land policy of common interest. Innovators have probably had ideas in this direction but unfortunately, the land data is still in the offices of the public bodies responsible for it. In Beninese sociology, it is information that is still little conveyed. Rational use of digital technologies in this sector can help mitigate the perverted effects observed if it is done by taking into account the weight of local sociology with respect to the land. Technology on its own will not be an obvious source of solutions to long-standing problems. Opening up land information to the general public can also have its share of social disaster in families where jealousy has taken on unimaginably harmful proportions. In conclusion, it is prudent to combine open data technology with the sociology of land uses to avoid obtaining effects contrary to the processes of democratization of land data.

Source :
(1) https://cadastre.bj/

indicators.justification: There is no evidence on the integrity of government actions. But it is the responsibility of the opponents of the political regime in place to find the flaws in governance and to enlighten the people's lens on the inconsistent elements. The independent organizations that can give voice on these subjects do not speak either.

There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.

indicators.justification:
The decisions and opinions of the public procurement regulator (1) help to consolidate trust between public procurement players. It is also important to stress that the preliminary work of the control (2) bodies is also an instrument for maintaining confidence and continuously improving the business climate.

Sources:
(1) https://armp.bj/category/documentation/recueils-de-decisions/
(2) https://www.marches-publics.bj/
